questions.explanation: Half adder Sum = A XOR B. XOR gives 1 when exactly one input is 1, which is the single-bit sum without carry.
Half adder Carry = A AND B. Carry is 1 only when both inputs are 1, requiring a 'carry' to the next bit position.

questions.prompt: Full adder has how many inputs?
questions.explanation: Full adder has 3 inputs: A, B, and Carry-in (Cin). This allows chaining for multi-bit addition.

questions.prompt: Full adder can be built from:
questions.explanation: Full adder = 2 half adders + 1 OR gate. First HA adds A,B; second HA adds result with Cin; OR combines carries.

questions.prompt: Even parity means total number of 1s is:
questions.explanation: Even parity: total count of 1s (including parity bit) must be even. Used for single-bit error detection.
Multi-input XOR outputs 1 if odd number of inputs are 1. This makes it perfect for parity generation/checking.
N-bit ripple carry adder needs N full adders, one per bit position, with carry rippling from LSB to MSB.
XNOR outputs 1 when inputs are equal. ANDing XNOR outputs for each bit position gives equality result.
Sum = A XOR B XOR Cin. This counts odd number of 1s among the three inputs, giving the sum bit.

questions.prompt: In parity checking, error is detected when:
questions.explanation: If computed parity of received data differs from expected (odd vs even), a single-bit error has occurred.

questions.prompt: A two-way light switch circuit uses:
questions.explanation: Two-way switch: light toggles when either switch changes. This is XOR behavior - output changes when inputs differ.
Cout = AB + Cin(A XOR B). Carry occurs when both A,B are 1, OR when Cin is 1 and A,B differ.
